PREFACE 
This Code constitutes a codification of the general and permanent ordinances of the County of Stephens, Georgia. 
Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the ordinances adopted by the board of commissioners. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any ordinance included herein. 
The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 

 
Index 
The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
This publication was under the direct supervision of Milton E. Lefkoff, Senior Code Attorney, and Sherry A. Albritton, Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
The publisher is most grateful to Mr. Russell Smith, County Attorney, and Nancy Downs, Clerk of the Board of Commissioners, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the county readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the county's affairs. 
Copyright 
All editorial enhancements of this Code are copyrighted by Municipal Code Corporation and the County of Stephens, Georgia. Editorial enhancements include, but are not limited to: organization; table of contents; section catchlines; prechapter section analyses; editor's notes; cross references; state law references; numbering system; code comparative table; state law reference table; and index. Such material may not be used or reproduced for commercial purposes without the express written consent of Municipal Code Corporation and the County of Stephens, Georgia.

ORDINANCE NO. 04-02 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW CODE FOR THE COUNTY OF STEPHENS COUNTY, GEORGIA; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS OF STEPHENS COUNTY, GEORGIA: 
Section 1. The Code entitled "The Code of Stephens County, Georgia" published by Municipal Code Corporation, consisting of chapters 1 through 82, each inclusive, is adopted. 
Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before July 8, 2003, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or of any other ordinance of the county shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, by imprisonment in the county jail for a period of time not to exceed 60 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, or up to the limits of any penalty provided by state law for the ordinance. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section, whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the county may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the board of commissioners to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
Section 6. Ordinances adopted after July 8, 2003, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
Section 7. This ordinance shall before [become] effective April 6, 2004. 
Passed and adopted by the board of commissioners this 6th day of April, 2004. 
Stephens County Board of Commissioner 
By: 

By: 

By: 


SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE 
  
The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Includes." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omits." 
In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution. 

 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes:

State Law reference— County boundaries, O.C.G.A. § 36-3-1 et seq. 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
The ordinances and other enactments embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as "The Code of Stephens County, Georgia," and may be so cited. It may also be referred to as "The Stephens County Code." 
Sec. 1-2. - General rules of construction; definitions. 
In the construction of this Code, the definitions and rules of construction in this section shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of commissioners. 
General. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirement adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provision imposed by this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. The ordinary signification shall be applied to all words, except words of art or words connected with a particular trade or subject matter, which shall have the signification attached to them by experts in such trade or with reference to such subject matter. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(b). 
Board, board of commissioners. The term "board" or "board of commissioners" shall mean the Board of Commissioners of Stephens County, Georgia. 
Code and this Code. Whenever the terms "Code" and "this Code" are referred to without further qualification, it shall mean The Code of Stephens County, Georgia, as designated in section 1-1. 
Computation of time. When a period of time measured in days, weeks, months, years or other measurements of time except hours is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, the first day shall not be counted but the last day shall be counted; if the last day falls on Saturday or Sunday, the person having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action falls on a public and legal holiday provided for in O.C.G.A. § 1-4-1, the person having the privilege or duty shall have through the next business day to exercise the privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(3). 
County. The term "the county" or "this county" shall mean Stephens County, Georgia. 
Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department of the county to do some act, it is to be construed to authorize him to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. 
Fee, charge, rate, deposit. The term "fee," "charge," "rate" or "deposit" shall mean a fee, charge, rate or deposit set from time to time by the board of commissioners and kept on file in the office of the board. 
Following. The term "following" means next after. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(8). 
Gender. The masculine gender shall include the feminine and the neuter. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(4). 
Joint authority. A joint authority given to any number of persons or officers may be executed by a majority of them. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(5). 
Keeper, proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" shall include persons, firms, associations, corporations, receivers, trustees, personal representatives, clubs and partnerships, whether acting by themselves or through a servant, agent or employee. 
Month. The term "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(11). 
Number. The singular or plural number shall each include the other. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(6). 
Oath. The term "oath" shall include affirmation. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(12). 
O.C.G.A. The abbreviation "O.C.G.A." shall mean the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, as amended. 
Officers, departments, etc. Whenever titles of various officers, employees, departments, boards, commissions or other agencies are used, they shall refer to such officers, employees, departments, boards, commissions or agencies of Stephens County, Georgia. 
Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common or tenant in partnership of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
Person. The term "person" shall extend and be applied to organizations, associations, clubs, societies, companies, proprietorships, firms, partnerships, either general or limited, joint ventures, trusts, estates, bodies politic and/or corporate, and other entities as well as to individuals. 
State Law reference— "Person" defined, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(14). 
Personal property. The term "personal property" shall include every species of property except real property. 
Preceding. The term "preceding" shall mean next before. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(15). 
Property. The term "property" shall include real and personal property. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(16). 
Public place. The term "public place" shall mean any park, cemetery, schoolyard or open space adjacent thereto, or any area available and/or accessible to the public, regardless of whether it is privately or publicly owned. 
Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
Residence. The term "residence" shall mean the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. 
Seal. The term "seal" shall mean the county seal. 
Shall, may. The term "shall" is mandatory; the term "may" is permissive. 
State Law reference— "May" defined, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(10). 
Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" shall mean that portion of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for use by pedestrians. 
State Law reference— "Sidewalk" defined, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1(57). 
Signature, subscription. The "signature" or "subscription" of a person shall include a mark of an illiterate or infirm person. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(19). 
State. The term "the state" or "this state" shall mean the State of Georgia. 
Street. The term "street" shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1(63). 
Tenant, occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
Tense. The present or past tense shall include the future. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(7). 
Week. The term "week" shall mean seven days. 
Writing. The term "writing" shall include printing and all numerals. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(23). 
Year. The term "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(24). 
Sec. 1-3. - Statutory rules of construction. 
Except as otherwise provided in this Code, the same rules shall be applied in construing provisions of this Code, and other ordinances of this county, as are applied in construing the statutes of this state, which rules are found in O.C.G.A. §§ 1-3-1—1-3-3, and the same meanings are to be given words found in the ordinances as are given similar words found in the statutes of this state. 
Sec. 1-4. - Catchlines and other headings. 
The catchlines of the sections of this Code and the headings of articles and divisions thereof are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents and shall not be deemed to be titles, nor as any part of the section, article or division, nor unless expressly so provided shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, articles or divisions, including the catchlines and headings, are amended or reenacted. No provision of this Code shall be held invalid because of deficiency in any such catchline or in any heading to any chapter, article or division. 
State Law reference— Notes and catchlines of Code sections not part of law, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-7. 
Sec. 1-5. - History notes. 
The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the sections. 
Sec. 1-6. - Editor's notes and references. 
The editor's notes, cross references and state law references in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to assist the user of this Code. 
Sec. 1-7. - Provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances. 
The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of ordinances existing on the adoption date of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-8. - Severability. 
The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code, and of codes or other provisions adopted by reference in this Code, are severable, and if any such phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section or the application thereof to any person or circumstance shall be declared invalid by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code and provisions adopted by reference, nor the application thereof to any persons or circumstances, since they would have been enacted by the board of commissioners without the incorporation therein of any such invalid phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
State Law reference— Severability of statutes, O.C.G.A. § 1-1-3. 
Sec. 1-9. - Penalties; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or in any other ordinance of the county any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of such provision shall be punishable by the imposition of a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, by imprisonment in the county jail for a period of time not to exceed 60 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment, or up to the limits of any penalty provided by state law for the ordinance. 
(b)  Each day any violation of this Code or other ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
State Law reference— Violations of county ordinances, O.C.G.A. §§ 15-10-60 et seq., 36-1-20; punishment for misdemeanors, O.C.G.A. § 17-10-3; nuisances, O.C.G.A. title 41. 
Sec. 1-10. - Provisions not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: 
(1)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(2)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the county or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the county or any evidence of the county's indebtedness. 
(3)  Any contract or obligation assumed by the county. 
(4)  Any right or franchise granted by the county. 
(5)  Any ordinance relating to specific public improvements or assessments therefor. 
(6)  Any ordinance, consistent with this Code, providing for the levy or collection of taxes or for an annual budget or appropriations. 
(7)  Any ordinance pertaining to zoning. 
(8)  Any ordinance relating to the investment of county funds. 
(9)  Any ordinance, consistent with this Code, prescribing regulations, compensation, positions, classification, retirement and other matters pertaining to county officers or employees. 
(10)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the county. 
(11)  Any ordinance naming, renaming, opening, closing, prescribing grades, etc., of streets, roads, bridges and other public ways. 
(12)  Any ordinance, consistent with this Code, establishing fees, rates, deposits, service charges or other charges. 
(13)  Any ordinance creating, establishing, prescribing or abolishing urban renewal projects. 
(14)  Any ordinance prescribing or providing traffic regulations at specific places, such as speed limits, through streets, stop intersections, yield intersections, one-way travel, no left turns, no right turns, traffic control by electrical devices, truck routes, loading zones, no parking zones and limited parking zones. 
(15)  Any ordinance continuing in force and effect local constitutional amendments. 
(16)  Any ordinance or resolution relating to civil defense or emergency management. 
All such ordinances are recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
Sec. 1-11. - Unlawful alteration of Code. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part of this Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner (except by ordinance or other official act of the board of commissioners or the General Assembly) which will cause the law of the county to be misrepresented. 
State Law reference— False writings and documents, O.C.G.A. § 16-10-20. 
Sec. 1-12. - Amendments; new provisions. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected by the repeal. Any and all additions and amendments to this Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the board of commissioners to make the same a part of this Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in this Code. A reference to this Code shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _____ of The Code of Stephens County, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows:…." The new provisions may then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That The Code of Stephens County, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section (or division, article or chapter) to be numbered _____, which reads as follows:…." The new section (or division, article or chapter) may then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or other provisions desired to be repealed should be repealed specifically by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
Sec. 1-13. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by county personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the board of commissioners. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive parts of permanent and general ordinances passed by the board during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become obsolete or partially obsolete. The new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In the preparation of a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by their omission from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances or parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them in a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize ordinances and resolutions into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinances incorporated in the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of the ordinance or resolution sections inserted in the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-14. - Effective date of ordinances and resolutions. 
Ordinances and resolutions which do not provide for their taking effect at a different time take effect immediately after their passage, or as otherwise provided by law. 
State Law reference— Effective date of legislative Acts, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-4. 
Sec. 1-15. - Effect of repeal of ordinances and resolutions. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance or resolution shall not revive any ordinance or resolution in force before or at the time the ordinance or resolution repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance or resolution shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance or resolution repealed, nor any right acquired or liability incurred under any ordinance or resolution repealed. 
State Law reference— Operation of laws, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-5. 
Sec. 1-16. - Ordinances powers effective. 
(a)  To carry into effect the powers and authority conferred upon Stephens County by the provisions of this chapter, or any past or future act of the Legislature of the State of Georgia, the governing body has plenary power and authority to: 
(1)  Make and pass all needful ordinances, orders, bylaws, acts, resolutions, rules and regulations not contrary to the constitution and laws of State of Georgia; and 
(2)  Prescribe reasonable penalties for violation of its ordinances, orders, bylaws, acts, resolutions, rules and regulations, in the form of fines, forfeitures and confinement in the county jail, for a term not exceeding thirty days per offense. 
(b)  The fines, forfeitures and confinement shall be recovered, imposed or enforced under the judgment of the Magistrate Court of Stephens County unless required to be brought in the Superior Court of Stephens County pursuant to the laws of the state. 
(Ord. of 1-26-2010) 
Sec. 1-17. - Ordinance procedures. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any chapter provision to the contrary, which chapter provision was in effect on the effective date of this section, it shall not be necessary, except where otherwise provided in this Code, for the governing body of Stephens County to publish in a newspaper any proposed ordinance prior to the adoption thereof or any enacted ordinance subsequent to the adoption thereof, and any and all ordinances of Stephens County shall be adopted in accordance with the following requirements, except where different or additional requirements are specified in other provisions of this Code, in which event such other different or additional requirements shall be applicable: 
(1)  A proposed ordinance shall be read by title at not less than two meetings of the governing body with at least one week intervening between each meeting, unless a member of the governing body demands that the ordinance be read in full at one or both meetings. If such demand is made, the ordinance shall be read in full as demanded. 
(2)  At least two weeks before the meeting at which a proposed ordinance is to be finally adopted, the governing body shall cause notice of the proposed adoption of said proposed ordinance, to be published as a legal advertisement, and the publication area for such publication shall be the legal section of the legal organ for Stephens County, Georgia. The notice shall state the subject matter in synopsis form and general title or titles of such proposed ordinance, the date, time and place of the proposed final vote on adoption, and the place or places within the county where the public may inspect such proposed ordinance. A reasonable number of copies of the proposed ordinance shall be kept at such place or places and be made available for public inspection. Said notice shall also advise that interested parties may appear at the meeting and be heard with respect to the proposed ordinance. 
(3)  A proposed ordinance shall not be materially amended at the same meeting at which finally adopted. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any chapter provision to the contrary, which chapter provision was in effect on the effective date of this section, the governing body of Stephens County may adopt, by ordinance, building codes, housing codes, plumbing codes, sanitary codes, electrical codes, fire prevention codes, or any other technical codes dealing with general public health, safety or welfare, or a combination of the same, or a comprehensive code of ordinances, in the manner prescribed in this subsection (b). 
(c)  Before any such ordinance shall be adopted, the code shall be either printed or typewritten and shall be presented in pamphlet form to the governing body of the county two weeks before a regular meeting, and copies of such code shall be made available for public inspection at same time. The ordinance adopting such code shall not set out said code in full, but shall merely identify the same. The vote on adoption of said ordinance shall be the same as on any other ordinance. After adoption of the ordinance, such code or codes shall be certified by the board of commissioners and shall be filed as a permanent record in the office of the Stephens County Clerk, who shall be required to transcribe and record the same in the ordinance book as other ordinances are transcribed and recorded. 
(d)  Consistent with the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, it shall not be necessary that any such ordinance, either as proposed or after adoption, be published in legal section of the newspaper, and it shall not be necessary that the code itself be so published, but before final adoption of any such proposed ordinance, notice of the proposed adoption of such ordinance and code shall be given by publication as herein provided for ordinances, the principal object of which notice shall also state where, within Stephens County, the code or codes will be available for public inspection. 
(e)  By a chapter framed and adopted, revision of a chapter as a whole, or a chapter amendment or amendments, as the case may be, subsequent to the effective date of this section, the county may require any or all ordinances to be published, two weeks in advance, in a legal section of the local newspaper prior to the adoption thereof, may expressly adopt the provisions of this section, may specify other additional requirements for the enactment of ordinances, or may prescribe a procedure for the enactment of ordinances in greater detail than prescribed in this section, but the county shall not, except in an emergency as specified in subsection (f) of this section, or except as otherwise provided in this code, have the power and authority to lessen or reduce the requirements of this section. 
(f)  The governing body of the county may enact an ordinance without complying with the rules prescribed in this section only: 
(1)  In the case of a pressing public emergency making procedure in accordance with the provisions of this section dangerous to the public health, safety or morals, and by affirmative vote of two-thirds of the members elected to the governing body; 
(2)  When otherwise provided in this Code. The nature of any such emergency shall be set out in full in the ordinance; or 
(3)  When deemed appropriate by affirmative vote of two-thirds of the members elected to the governing body and not otherwise required by Georgia law. 
(g)  Each ordinance when adopted shall be entered in the ordinance record book, and the original copy of the ordinance shall be kept in clerk records along with the minutes of the meeting in which the ordinance received its second reading and was enacted. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful to change or amend by addition or deletion any part of the ordinances or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with the ordinances in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the Stephens County to be misrepresented. 
(Ord. of 1-26-2010) 
Sec. 1-18. - Resolutions records. 
(a)  Each resolution shall, before its introduction, be reduced to printed or typewritten form and shall be signed by the person who introduces it; and the clerk shall then number it, and, when adopted, shall spread it in full upon the minutes of board of commission. The clerk shall then place the original copy of such resolution in his/her office in a file to be known as the record of resolutions. 
(b)  Resolutions and portions of resolutions which are repealed or amended by subsequent resolutions or ordinances shall be noted and initialed in the margin thereof by the clerk, so as to show the date and number of the repealing or amendatory ordinance or resolution, but shall not be removed from the record of resolutions. 
(Ord. of 1-26-2010) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any contract or obligation assumed by the county saved from repeal, § 1-10(3); any ordinance, consistent with this Code, establishing fees, rates, deposits, service charges or other charges saved from repeal, § 1-10(12); civil emergencies, ch. 26; courts, ch. 30; administration of flood damage prevention, § 38-61 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 42; personnel, ch. 54; planning, ch. 58; taxation, ch. 70; utilities, ch. 82. 
State Constitution reference— Counties and municipal corporations, Ga. Const. art. IX; home rule for counties, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ I. 
State Law reference— County government, O.C.G.A. title 36; emergency interim successors to officials, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-50. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Form of county government. 
The county shall be organized in accordance with a county administrator form of county government. 
Sec. 2-2. - Inspection of public records. 
All records maintained by the board of commissioners, as defined and set forth in O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq., are declared to be available for inspection and for the purpose of making photographs or reproductions of same by any interested member of the public in accordance with the following rules and regulations and subject to the following exceptions: 
(1)  The board determines it in the best interest of the county that an orderly procedure be developed for inspection of the public records of the board, that the board have and maintain a record of those persons inspecting the public records, and that the board maintain a record of the time and expense occasioned by the inspection of the public records, and to that end determines that a written record be maintained of those persons inspecting the public records of the board. 
(2)  Any member of the public desiring to inspect, photograph or reproduce any records maintained by the board shall complete an application for inspection. The application shall be on the form attached to the resolution from which this section is derived as exhibit "A" and incorporated in this section by reference. The clerk of the board of commissioners shall maintain an adequate supply of application forms and shall deliver, free of charge, reasonable quantities of such forms to members of the public making requests for inspection of such records. The clerk shall further mail to any person making a request by letter or by telephone an application for inspection. A written or verbal request containing substantial information requested on the application for inspection shall be deemed sufficient and the written request shall serve in lieu of the written application for inspection. 
(3)  Upon receipt of a completed application for inspection or a written request equivalent to an application, the clerk of the board of commissioners shall determine the time and expense that the inspection of the requested records shall entail, and whether or not the requested records fall within an exception to those records otherwise available for public inspection. The clerk of the board of commissioners shall produce for inspection all records responsive to a request within a reasonable amount of time not to exceed three business days of receipt of a request: provided, that nothing shall require agencies to produce records in response to a request if such records do not exist at the time of the request. In any instance where records are unavailable within three business days of receipt of the request, and responsive records exist, the clerk of the board of commissioners shall within such time period, provide the requestor with a description of such records and a timeline for when the records will be available. If the clerk determines that the requested records can be promptly made available to the inquiring person without considerable expense, time, or undue interruption of the normal business routine of the clerk's office, and that the requested information is not in that category of records not available for public inspection, the clerk shall immediately make available for inspection the records requested. The inspection shall be done under the supervision of the clerk , and the records may not be removed from the offices of the board while the inspection is in progress. The person desiring the inspection shall be allowed a comfortable table and chair at which the inspection shall be made. The clerk or any designated employee of the county shall have the right to remain present at all times to determine that no records are amended, altered, deleted, or removed as a result of the inspection. 
(4)  The person making the inspection shall have the right to make photographs or reproductions of the records with a camera or other copying device that the inspecting person may bring with him or her. 
(5)  Upon request, the board will, subject to time and work limitations, make photocopies of public records as may be requested by the person making application, using such photocopying machines or equipment that may be available from time to time for use by the board. 
(6)  If an extensive review or inspection of the public records is desired or immediate inspection would result in undue interruption, the clerk of the board of commissioners shall advise the person making application of the time and place at which the inspection shall be allowed. The inspection shall be allowed as soon as reasonably possible. 
(7)  If the clerk of the board of commissioners determines that the requested inspection involves records which are not open for public inspection, the clerk shall advise the person making application that the application will be referred to the board for determination as to whether or not the inspection will be allowed. 
(8)  For the work relating to the inspection and/or copying, the person desiring the inspection and/or copying and/or services of the clerk of the board of commissioners or any designated employee shall pay the following charges: 
a.  The sum of $0.10 per page for each page copied by the board at the request of the person making the application. 
b.  If, in supplying the information or furnishing the records for inspection or making copies thereof, the time expended by any employee of the board exceeds one-fourth hour, a charge for the search, retrieval, or redaction of records not to exceed the prorated hourly salary of the lowest paid full-time employee who, in the reasonable discretion of the custodian of the records, has the necessary skill and training to perform the request, the person making application shall, prior to being furnished the records requested, pay to the board as reimbursement to the county the maximum sum authorized in O.C.G.A. § 50-18-71(d). 
(9)  Except as otherwise provided by law, the following records shall not be available for inspection: 
a.  Any records prohibited by law or the order of any court or any law of this state from being opened to inspection by the general public. 
b.  Any records specifically required by the federal government to be kept confidential. 
(10)  Any application may be denied because the requesting party desires to inspect a broad, and undifferentiated, mass of material. In case of the receipt of such an application, the board shall ask the requesting party to set forth identifiable, public records within the board's possession which the person desires to inspect. 
(11)  Nothing contained in this section shall be construed so as to make available for public inspection any records excluded by O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq., and by the judicial interpretation of such statute. 
(12)  To the extent that any paragraph of this section conflicts with the Georgia Open Records Act, the provisions of the Georgia Open Records Act shall control. 
(Res. of 2-20-1979; Ord. of 5-22-2012) 
Secs. 2-3—2-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS 

Sec. 2-31. - Governing authority. 
The governing authority of the county shall be a board of five commissioners, who shall be elected as provided by law. 
(Ord. of 5-22-2012) 
Sec. 2-32. - Time of holding meetings. 
The time for regular meetings of the board of commissioners shall be at 5:00 p.m. on the second Tuesday of each month; and 8:30 a.m. on the fourth Tuesday of each month. 
(Res. of 1-7-1975; Res. of 1-4-1977; Res. No. 2010-19, 7-13-2010; Ord. of 5-22-2012) 
Sec. 2-33. - Commissioner incentives. 
The board of commissioners must complete a mandatory 48 hours of certification to become a certified county commissioner. A certified commissioners advance program (CCAP) can be achieved through 48 hours of continuing education. Once a commissioner has completed this program and CCAP certification or the future equivalent of CCAP certification, he or she shall receive a supplemental pay incentive of $100.00 per month. The purpose of the incentive is to encourage county commissioners to achieve as much additional training and certification as possible with the understanding that better trained commissioners will be more effective county commissioners and more capable of serving the needs of the citizens of Stephens County. 
(Ord. of 5-22-2012) 
Secs. 2-34—2-60. - Reserved.

The county marshal/code enforcement officer shall be responsible for the enforcement of all county ordinances. The county marshal/code enforcement officer shall not exercise any arrest powers but shall be limited to issuing citations for violation of county ordinances and may take out arrest warrants for other law enforcement officers to execute.

(b)  The chief marshal shall be compensated solely on a salary basis and not in whole or part from fees and the salary shall be paid in equal bi-weekly installments from county funds in an amount to be set by the commission.

ARTICLE V. - FINANCE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the county or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the county or any evidence of the county's indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-10(2); taxation, ch. 70. 

Sec. 2-121. - Fiscal year. 
(a)  The fiscal year for the county shall commence on July 1 and end on June 30 of each year, and all county officials shall keep their official accounts in accordance therewith. 
(b)  All public officers of the county shall conform to the fiscal year as established in subsection (a) of this section in reporting and recording the financial operations of their respective offices and departments. 
(Res. of 6-18-1974) 
Sec. 2-122. - Signing of checks. 
(a)  The chairman of the board of commissioners and the clerk of the board of commissioners or the vice-chairman or finance director shall sign all checks by which county funds are expended. 
(b)  The vice-chairman of the board of commissioners is given full power and authority to sign all checks in the absence of the chairman. 
(c)  The finance director of the board of commissioners is given full power and authority to sign all checks in the absence of the clerk of the board of commissioners. 
(Res. of 1-1-1974; Res. of 2-19-1974; Res. of 9-2-1975; Res. of 1-21-1975(1); Ord. of 5-22-2012) 
Sec. 2-123. - Management of budget. 
The following financial management policies establish the overall basic framework for the management of the county. These policies will provide assistance to the commissioners and county administrator by providing guidance in the decision-making process of the county. These policies will provide the guidelines for evaluating both current activities and proposals for future programs. These policies shall be reviewed annually by the board and changes made as the council deems appropriate. 
(1)  The operating budget authorizing the expenditure of county monies shall be adopted annually not later than the last meeting in the fiscal year preceding the fiscal year to which the budget applies. 
(2)  The operating budget shall be balanced in all funds. 
(3)  The county will attempt to maintain its present services level for all high priority and essential services. 
(4)  The county will continue to search for additional revenue. 
(5)  The county will take active measures to encourage economic development resulting in increased jobs and tax base. 
(6)  The county will aggressively seek federal and state funds. 
(7)  All investments of county funds shall be made through financial institutions located within the county, provided the rates are reasonably competitive. 
(8)  The county will have an independent audit of the county's financial records performed annually. The reports shall comply with generally accepted accounting principles. 
(9)  The county has written purchasing rules and regulations incorporated in the Stephens County Purchasing Manual as amended effective date of January 2009 and June 2011. 
a.  All purchases with an estimated total cost of a minimum of $1,000.00 to $5,000.00 shall submit three required competitive telephone quotations with purchase order unless adequate source is not available. Any budgeted purchases within this range require approval of the department head and county administrator. 
b.  Competitive written quotations shall be submitted with purchase orders from $5,000.01 to $15,000.00. A minimum of three quotations is required unless adequate source of supply is not available. Any budgeted purchase within this range requires authorization of county administrator and board of commissioners. 
c.  Competitive written quotations shall be submitted with purchase orders from $15,000.01. A minimum of three quotations is required unless adequate source supply is not available. All purchases above this range, budgeted or non-budgeted, require a sealed competitive bid, to be opened in public and approved by the board of commissioners. 
d.  The county administrator and any one commissioner; the finance director and any one commissioner shall be authorized to make emergency purchases when there is a threat to public health, welfare, safety, infrastructure, or county property, to either the county and/or its citizens. The emergency purchase order shall not exceed $20,000.00 without prior approval by the board of commissioners. The emergency purchase order shall be brought before the board of commissioners no later than the next regularly scheduled meeting. Staff should consider the dynamics of emergency to determine if a special called meeting of the board needs to be called and further emergency purchasing procedures need to be implemented. 
e.  To eliminate the staff spending unnecessary time in collecting bids, the board of commissioners authorizes county departments to utilize state and federal bids where applicable. 
(10)  The county has bid and contract procedures: Local bidder three percent preference: Facts: Bidder "A" an out-of-county bidder bids $10,000.00. Bidder "B" a county bidder bids $10,250.00 and bidder "C" a county bidder bids $10,400.00. Preference: Bidder "B" will be contacted and given 48 hours to meet the bid of bidder "A" since the local bidder's bid is within three percent of the out-of-town bidder $10,300.00. If bidder "B" agrees to meet the bid price of bidder "A" by written confirmation, the board of commissioners may award the contract to bidder "B". If bidder "B" declines to accept the award, bidder "A" would be awarded the bid since bidder "C's" (a second local bidder) bid is not within three percent of the low out-of-town bid. 
(Mo. of 6-21-1994; Ord. of 5-22-2012) 
Sec. 2-124. - Investment of county funds. 
(a)  The investment authority of the board of commissioners as granted in O.C.G.A. § 36-80-3 shall be delegated by the board of commissioners pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-80-4, subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  The designee of the board of commissioners shall invest the funds under the control and jurisdiction of the board only in those investments which are authorized by the law of the state for such funds. 
(2)  The funds shall be invested only with financial institutions located in the county which have available lawfully authorized investments. 
(3)  The funds shall be invested at the highest rate of interest available from a financial institution in the county offering authorized investments for the time period for which the funds are sought to be invested. 
(4)  Funds shall be invested in such an amount as the finance director of the board of commissioners determines feasible, taking into account the cash needs of the board of commissioners so that the necessary funds to cover the expenses of the county are available as needed. 
(5)  The delegation of the investment authority granted in this section shall continue until revoked by general law of the state or by further action of the board of commissioners. 
(b)  The designee of the board of commissioners is authorized to sign on behalf of the board such documents as may be necessary in order to exercise the investment authority delegated in this section, and a certified copy of this section shall be sufficient proof of the authority of the designee of the board to act as authorized in this section. 
(Res. of 1-8-1985; Ord. of 5-22-2012) 
Chapter 3 - UNIFORM POLICIES AND PROCEDURES FOR THE CALLING AND CONDUCTING OF PUBLIC HEARINGS RELATING TO VARIOUS COUNTY LAND USE ORDINANCES, ZONING AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES 

Sec. 3-1. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Zoning and Land Use Public Hearing Policies and Procedures Ordinance of Stephens County, Georgia" (hereinafter referred to as the "chapter"). 
(Ord. No. 2010-4, 1-26-2010) 
Sec. 3-2. - Intent. 
As the governing body of Stephens County, Georgia ("Stephens County"), it is the intention of the Stephens County Board of Commissioners ("governing body") to adopt a chapter enacting uniform practices and procedures to govern the calling and conducting of public hearings relating to Stephens County's various land use and zoning ordinances which now exist or which may be hereafter enacted, including without limitation, those hearings required by the Georgia Zoning Procedures Law (O.C.G.A. § 36-66-5 et seq., as amended). 
(Ord. No. 2010-4, 1-26-2010) 
Sec. 3-3. - Definitions. 
The following terms when used in this chapter with the first letter capitalized shall have the meanings given in this section: 
Person. An individual, firm, partnership, corporation, company, association, institution, public official or public body including any trustee, assignee or other representative and including, without limitation, the governing body and the planning committee. 
Property Owner. The person or persons who own property being considered under any zoning or land use ordinance. 
Zoning or Land Use Ordinance. Any zoning ordinance, the subdivision regulations or land use regulations, adopted as heretofore or hereafter amended and any other Stephens County land use ordinance which may by its terms provide that this chapter shall be applicable thereto. 
Zoning Ordinance. Any ordinance or resolution of Stephens County, whether now existing or hereafter enacted, which falls within the definition of "zoning ordinance" provided by the Zoning Procedures Law (O.C.G.A. §36-66-3 (5)) or any successor provision thereto or any ordinance or resolution of Stephens County that requires compliance with the Zoning Procedures Law. 
Zoning Procedure Law. The State of Georgia Zoning Procedures Law, O.C.G.A. title 36, chapter 66, enacted by Georgia Laws 1985, page 1139, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 2010-4, 1-26-2010) 
Sec. 3-4. - Applicability. 
These policies and procedures shall apply to all hearings of the governing body relating to any of the following: 
(a)  The adoption of any Zoning or Land Use Ordinance; 
(b)  The adoption of any amendment to or restatement of any Zoning or Land Use Ordinance which changes the text of the ordinance; 
(c)  The adoption of any amendment to the official zoning map which rezones property from one zoning classification to another; 
(d)  The issuance of any conditional use permit under any Zoning or Land Use Ordinance; 
(e)  The grant of any variance under any Zoning or Land Use Ordinance; 
(f)  The adoption of any amendment to or restatement of this chapter; and 
(g)  Any other action requiring a public hearing pursuant to the Zoning Procedures Law. 
(Ord. No. 2010-4, 1-26-2010) 
Sec. 3-5. - Procedures for adoption of amendment of text of Zoning or Land Use Ordinances and this chapter. 
(a)  Initiation of changes. The governing body may from time to time, on its own motion, or, in its discretion, upon recommendation of staff or any other Person, initiate a proposal to adopt, or to amend or restate the text of, any Zoning or Land Use Ordinance or to amend or restate this chapter. 
(b)  Submission of proposals. Any proposal to adopt, or to amend or restate the text of, any Zoning or Land Use Ordinance or to amend or restate this chapter which the governing body initiates shall be submitted by the governing body to staff for review and recommendation. 
(c)  Call of public hearings. Upon receipt of any such proposal the governing body shall set the dates, times, and places for holding a public hearing before the governing body to consider the proposed action. No final action may be taken by the governing body until after the public hearing of the governing body has been concluded. 
(d)  Notice of public hearings. After the date, time and place for a public hearing has been set, the governing body shall cause notice of the hearing to be published at least one time in a newspaper of general circulation in Stephens County at least 15 days but not more than 45 days prior to the date of the public hearing. Such published notice shall include, as a minimum, the purpose, location, date and time of the public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2010-4, 1-26-2010) 
Sec. 3-6. - Conduct of public hearings. 
All public hearings held by the governing body to which this ordinance applies shall be held in accordance with the following procedures: 
(1)  The presiding officer shall open the public hearing by stating the matter being considered at the hearing. At this time the presiding officer may summarize the public hearing procedures. 
(2)  The applicant will present a description of the proposal, and any applicable background material. 
(3)  Persons who support the proposal will be asked to comment first. The Person initiating the proposal or his designated agent (the "proponent") may, upon recognition and upon statement of name, address and relationship to the matter, present and explain the proposal. The proponent shall be required to attend the public hearing unless written notice of hardship is received prior to the hearing. Failure of the proponent to attend the public hearing, except in cases of hardship, may be due cause for dismissal or denial of such application. After completion of the presentation of the proponent, other persons who support proposal will be asked to comment, and will be allowed to speak in support of the proposal upon recognition and upon identification of the Person's name, address, and relationship to the matter. 
(4)  Persons who oppose the proposal will next be asked to comment. All interested Persons, after being recognized and providing their names, addresses and relationship to the matter, shall be afforded an opportunity to address the proposal. 
(5)  The proponent shall have an opportunity for summary remarks rebuttal concerning the proposed application. 
(6)  The presiding officer, in his discretion, may impose time limitations on comments of each Person not less than ten minutes, and may require that each Person (other than any Stephens County official or his agent) who desires to speak sign in at the beginning of the meeting and indicate whether such Person will be speaking for or against the proposal 
(7)  All public comments having been heard, the members of the governing body considering the application may discuss the matter among themselves. During this discussion period, the members of the body may call on the proponent or other Persons to clarify points made previously, to answer questions or to provide additional information. Such Persons may respond upon recognition. 
(8)  Public hearings may be delayed, rescheduled or continued to another time and date, provided announcement is given at the time and place of the scheduled hearing, of the new time, place and date of the public hearing, which announcement shall constitute public notice for the hearing. Upon conclusion of the hearing, the presiding officer shall adjourn the hearing. 
(9)  The presiding officer or the applicant may require that any public hearing be transcribed by a court reporter provided that such Person has made arrangements with the court reporter to have the court reporter attend and transcribe the hearing. All costs of any court reporter shall be borne by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2010-4, 1-26-2010) 
Sec. 3-7. - Severability. 
Should any article, section or provision of this chapter be declared invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, such declaration shall not affect the validity of this chapter as a whole or any part thereof which is not specifically declared to be invalid. 
(Ord. No. 2010-4, 1-26-2010) 
Sec. 3-8. - Public availability. 
Printed copies of this chapter shall be made available for distribution to the general public. 
Sec. 3-9. - Repealer. 
This chapter shall supersede all portions of any ordinances or resolutions which are in conflict herewith. 
(Ord. No. 2010-4, 1-26-2010) 
Sec. 3-10. - Effective date. 
This chapter shall become effective immediately upon its adoption. 
(Ord. No. 2010-4, 1-26-2010) 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. of 10-27-2009 amended ch. 6 in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former ch. 6 derived from Ord. No. 93-2, §§ 1—24. 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 22; use and possession of alcoholic beverages in parks, § 50-2. 
State Law reference— Local alcoholic beverage licenses, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2 et seq.; local regulation of distilled spirits, O.C.G.A. § 34-40 et seq.; local regulation of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40 et seq.; local regulation of wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-40; public drunkenness, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-41. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 6-1—6-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MALT BEVERAGES AND WINE 
PURPOSE 
Be it ordained by the Stephens County Board of Commissioners, for the purposes of: 
Promoting the health and general welfare of the community; 
Establishing reasonable and ascertainable standards for the regulation and control of the licensing and sale of alcoholic beverages; 
Protecting and preserving schools and churches' and 
Preventing undesirable persons from engaging in or having any interest in alcoholic beverages; it is hereby ordained as follows: 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, from whatever source or by whatever process produced. 
Alcoholic beverage means and includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverage, wine, or fortified wine as defined in this section. 
Board means the Stephens County Board of Commissioners. 
Brown bagging means possession of an open glass bottle, can, or other container containing an alcoholic beverage or consumption of an alcoholic beverage on any premises for which a county business license has been issued, and occurs at a location different from where the alcoholic beverage was purchased. 
Clerk means the clerk of the board of commissioners. 
Church means any permanent building which houses the main sanctuary in which persons regularly assemble for religious worship and which is publicly designated as a church and which is either owned or held under a lease of at least five years by or on behalf of such persons, but shall not include a residence also used for religious purposes. The term "church" shall not include the temporary housing of a religious group in an otherwise commercial center. 
Code enforcement officer means the Stephens County Sheriff Department, Stephens County Marshal, or any individual so designated by the board. 
Distilled spirits means any alcoholic beverage obtained by distillation or containing more than 21 percent alcohol by volume, including, but not limited to, all fortified wines. 
Election day means that period of time beginning with the opening of the polls and ending with the closing of the polls. As used in this chapter, the term "election" is defined as any statewide primary election and the statewide general election and any runoff held for such primary or general election. Such term also includes local elections, 
Financial interest includes, but is not limited to, holding any indebtedness or security interest in a business. 
Licensee means the individual to whom a license is issued, or, in the case of a partnership, limited liability company or corporation, all partners, members, managers, officers, and directors of the partnership, limited liability company or corporation and in the case of any other business entity, any person filling an analogous role in such entity. 
Licensed premises means any premises in which alcoholic beverages are sold or dispensed for consumption on the premises and shall include any premises which are required by law to be licensed to sell or dispense alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. 
Liter means metric measurement currently used by the United States. 
Malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops, or any other similar product or any combination of such products in water, containing not more than six [bottles], 9.5 percent alcohol by volume, and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer, and strong beer. The term does not include sake, known as Japanese rice wine. Also included are beverages known as "nonalcoholic" beer." 
Minor is defined pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23, as enacted or amended. 
Nonprofit private club means any nonprofit association organization under the laws of the state which: 
(1)  Has been in existence at least one year prior to the filing of its application for a license to be issued pursuant to this chapter; 
(2)  Has at least 75 regular dues-paying members; 
(3)  Owns, hires, or leases a building or space within a building for the reasonable use of its members, which building or space: 
a.  Has suitable kitchen and dining room space and equipment; and 
b.  Is staffed with a sufficient number of employees for cooking, preparing, and serving meals for its members and guests; Georgia code O.C.G.A. § 3-7-1; and 
(4)  Has no member, officer, agent, or employee directly or indirectly receiving, in the form of salary or other compensation, any profits from the sale of alcoholic beverages beyond a fixed salary. 
Owner means any person, corporation, or partnership or any other entity having a financial interest in the income of the business. Owner shall also include any person, corporation, or partnership operating a business under a management contract. 
Operator means and includes the owner, license holder, operator, manager, and person in charge of any licensed premises. 
Peace officer means any peace officer, county marshal, sheriff, or any other county designee. 
Person means any individual, firm, partnership, cooperative, nonprofit membership corporation, joint venture, association, company, corporation, agency, syndicate, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, fiduciary, or other group or combination acting as a unit, body politic, or political subdivision, whether public, private, or quasi-public. Person shall include all members of a retail dealer licensee's family. 
Premises means the space or area owned, leased, or controlled by a licensee pursuant to this chapter and used by him for the purpose of operating under the license and there shall be a separate license for each premises outlet. In the case of a licensee where a golf course is located adjacent to and contiguous with a restaurant, the term "premises" shall include the playing area of the golf course. 
Resident means a person whose primary residence is within the territorial limits of the county. 
Restaurant means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are served and where meals are actually and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such place being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and a seating capacity of at least 50 people, with at least two meals per day being served for not less than five days a week, for at least nine months each calendar year, and the serving of alcoholic beverages to be consumed on the premises as only incidental thereto. A minimum of 50 percent of its gross income deriving from the sale of such meals or appetizers, with each sale, which includes an alcoholic beverage including a reasonable order of a meal or appetizer. 
School means governmental or church school buildings and such buildings at such other schools as teach the subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of this state. The term "school building" includes only those structures in which instruction is offered. 
Stephens County is a political subdivision of the State of Georgia and, for the purposes of this chapter, the unincorporated portions thereof. 
Package means a bottle, can, keg, barrel, or other original consumer container. 
Retail package means sales of malt beverages or wine packaged to go and not for consumption on-the-premises sales. 
Retail consumption dealer means any person who sells alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises, at retail, only to consumers and not for resale. 
Retail package dealer means any person who sells unbroken packages, at retail, only to consumers and not for resale. 
Tax means the tax imposed by this chapter. 
Veterans' organization means a veterans group duly certified by their national organization and with a membership of not less than 25 persons. 
Wine means any alcoholic beverage containing not more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries, or grapes, either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines, champagnes, and combinations of such beverages, vermouths, special natural wines, rectified wines and like products. The term does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. A liquid shall first be deemed to be a wine at that point in the manufacturing process when it conforms to the definition of wine contained in this section. 
(Ord. of 10-27-2009) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 3-7-1. 
Sec. 6-32. - Violations. 
Any firm, person or corporation who shall do anything prohibited by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended or who shall fail to do anything required by this chapter as the same exists or as it may hereafter be amended shall be guilty of a violation of a county ordinance, amenable to the process of the magistrate court of the county and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 or by confinement in the county jail not to exceed 60 days, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(1)  It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person, including the licensee, to engage in any activity on the premises for which the license is issued or within the place of business which is in violation of the laws or regulations of the state or federal government or any ordinance of Stephens County. 
(2)  Any person holding any license issued pursuant to this chapter or any employee or agent of such person who violates any provision of this chapter, or directs, consents to, permits, or acquiesces in such violation either directly or indirectly shall, by such conduct, subject the license to suspension, revocation or probation upon conditions. In addition, a maximum civil fine of $1,000.00 and/or up to 60 days in county jail, for each violation. In considering the amount of the civil fine, if any, the administrative hearing officer shall consider the following factor: 
a.  The gravity of the violation; 
b.  Any previous violations for which a fine was not assessed or for which the administrative hearing officer reduced and assessed fine; 
c.  The cost to Stephens County related to compliance or enforcement efforts undertaken by Stephens County in pursuing the case; and 
d.  The cost incurred by Stephens County in order to mitigate a condition remaining as the result of the violation. 
(3)  The imposition of a civil fine under the provisions of this section shall not prevent the suspension, revocation, or nonrenewal of the license or the taking of punitive or remedial action for any other violation of the ordinances of Stephens County or for subsequent violations of this section. No license shall be renewed if the licensee prior to renewal has not paid any civil fines imposed pursuant to this section. Any action taken by the administrative hearing officer to suspend or revoke a license issued hereunder, shall not preclude, and may be in addition to, any criminal prosecution by a proper authority as provided by the laws and ordinances of the county, the state, or the United States. Whenever any action is taken by the administrative hearing officer to suspend or revoke any license issued hereunder, the administrative hearing officer shall provide written notice to the licensee of the action taken and state the reasons therefore. The licensee shall have 15 days following notification of such action to request a hearing before the governing authority. The licensee shall be entitled at such hearing to present evidence and cross-examine opposing witnesses. 
(4)  The Stephens County Sheriff, the Stephens County Marshal, or a code enforcement officer as designated by the board is authorized to conduct any enforcement actions necessary to determine compliance with this chapter. 
(5)  It shall be a violation not to require and properly check the identification to ensure that an underage person is not sold, served, or does not have in his possession alcoholic beverages while in a licensed establishment. Identification in this section shall mean any document issued by a governmental agency containing a description of the person, such person's photograph and giving such person's date of birth and shall include, without being limited to, a passport, military ID card, driver's license or state department or [of] public safety ID card. 
(6)  Except as otherwise specifically provided for by law, it is unlawful for any person to sell, possess, conceal, store, or convey any alcoholic beverage on which any tax or license fee imposed by this chapter has not been paid (O.C.G.A. § 3-2-33a). 
(7)  The license shall not permit the breaking of the package or packages on the premises where sold and shall not permit the drinking of the contents of the package or packages on the premises where sold (O.C.G.A. § 3-4-25). 
(8)  Malt beverages in quantities exceeding the amount specified in O.C.G.A. § 3-3-8, upon which the taxes imposed by or authorized pursuant to this chapter have not been paid in this state, are declared to be contraband; and any motor vehicle, watercraft, or aircraft used in transporting such beverages in excess of the amount specified in O.C.G.A. § 3-3-8 are also declared to be contraband and subject to seizure and disposition as provided by this chapter (O.C.G.A. § 3-5-3(b)). 
(Ord. of 10-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-33. - Remedies. 
If any provision of this chapter has been violated or is being violated, in addition to other remedies, the county may institute injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceeding to protect or abate such violation. 
(Ord. of 10-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-34. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  The hours of sale of packaged malt beverages and wines shall be between 7:00 a.m. to 11:45 p.m., Monday through Saturday and 12:30 p.m. to 11:30 p.m. on Sundays. The hours of sale for consumption on the premises of malt beverages and wines shall be 11:00 a.m. to 12:45, Monday through Friday and 12:30 p.m. to 12:00 midnight on Sundays. Hours on Saturday and Christmas Eve shall be 8:00 a.m. to 11:45 p.m. 
(b)  If a licensed business is open for less than the hours stated in subsection (a), then sales of malt beverages and wines shall be restricted to those regular store hours. However, in no event shall sales be made during hours other than described in subsection (a). 
(c)  All holders of licenses issued hereunder must, within three months after the issuance of such license, open for business the establishment referred to in the license. Failure to open the licensed establishment as referred to within such period shall serve as forfeiture and cancellation of the unused license and no refund of license fee shall be made to the license holder. 
(Ord. of 10-27-2009; Ord. of 1-22-2019) 
State Law reference— O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20 (2009) 
Sec. 6-35. - Advertising. 
Licensees under this chapter shall not display any sign or decal either outside the premises or at any location in the county, which advertises the sale of malt beverages and wines, either directly, indirectly, or by inference or suggestion. Any advertising signs within the principal building shall not be displayed within view of the general public from the outside of the building. The county shall provide for all retail and consumption licensees an orange decalcomania sign to post on the front of the licensed location. 
(1)  Any license obtained under this chapter shall be displayed on the licensed premised in public view. 
(2)  Each licensee shall also post in a conspicuous place a sign with letters at least two inches in size stating: "The sale of alcoholic beverages to persons under the age of 21 years is strictly prohibited". 
(3)  Retail package licensees shall indicate plainly by tags or labels on the bottles or containers or on the edge of the shelf immediately below or above where the containers are placed the price of an alcoholic beverage exposed or offered for sale. No other sign may be exposed within or without the retail establishment showing prices or indicating that alcoholic beverages are for sale on the premises. 
(4)  No person holding a retail dealer's license to deal in distilled spirits by the package shall display any advertisement of or information regarding the price or prices of any distilled spirits in any show window or other place visible from outside the licensee's place of business. 
(5)  All retail consumption dealers and retail dealers in this state who sell at retail any alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall post, in a conspicuous place, a sign which clearly reads: Warning: "Drinking alcoholic beverage during pregnancy can cause birth defects". 
(Ord. of 10-27-2009) 
Sec. 6-36. - Underage persons. 
(a)  If any license holder, agents or employees of license holders under this article sell alcoholic beverages to a person under the legal age to purchase alcoholic beverages as provided by state law, the license shall be suspended for a minimum of 30 days.
